awd_titl_txt: Identifying Catalysts for Increasing Student Diversity in Engineering in a Predominantly White Institution
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by building institutional capacity for broadening participation in undergraduate engineering. Colleges of Engineering in predominantly white institutions continue to struggle to recruit, retain and successfully matriculate their non-white students.  Using a systems approach, this project aims to identify catalysts that can unify programmatic efforts to produce greater institutional success in broadening participation. These catalysts can exist throughout an organization, and can take the form of people, knowledge, money, policies, built environments, and other resources. A coherent set of programmatic efforts can lead to greater transformative power and sustainability. The project will generate templates that other colleges of engineering in the United States can use to discover and understand their own capacities and to further their own recruitment, retention and graduation efforts for students from underrepresented groups. The ultimate aim of the project is to enable the success of a diverse pool of engineering graduates, and to strengthen the diversity of the engineering workforce. 

The goals of the project are to generate systemwide capacity change catalysts in a College of Engineering at a predominantly white institution. The project conceptualizes the college as a complex sociotechnical organization with two subsystems at work. The social subsystem consists of people such as students, faculty, staff, and administrators. The technical subsystem consists of elements that can impact capacity building, including goals, policies, processes, programs, data, technology, and know-how. The project uses semi-structured interviews and ideation focus groups with students, faculty, and staff from admissions, advising, and career services as well as administrative leaders. Results will be used to model the sociotechnical system, to develop system capacity matrices and social focal role networks, and to generate capacity change catalysts. The project contributes to identifying and understanding, in-depth, the systemwide catalysts in predominantly white engineering colleges that will enable these colleges to improve their capacity to recruit, retain and successfully matriculate underrepresented students. The project also contributes a new sociotechnical systems lens and lays out a template for using the lens to model an educational unit. The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students. Through the Institutional and Community Transformation track, the program supports efforts to transform and improve STEM education across institutions of higher education and disciplinary communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Systems Engineering Initiative for Student Success (SEISS) Framework was developed to model and analyze educational organizations, specifically focusing on the challenges faced by underrepresented minority (URM) students in engineering programs. The SEISS framework adopts a holistic approach by examining multiple interconnected factors from recruitment to graduation. It includes organizational, technical, and social subsystem analyses. Findings indicated that key enabling attributes for student success included professional development opportunities and participation in professional organizations, whereas hindering factors included curriculum difficulties. Communication among system members primarily revolved around achieving goals and long-term development, with integration challenges noted for URM students. Supporting URM students can lead to broader impacts such as developing role models, enhancing diversity in STEM, and fostering innovation.

This research is significant because it provides a comprehensive framework, the Systems Engineering Initiative for Student Success (SEISS), for understanding and addressing the multifaceted challenges faced by underrepresented minority (URM) students in engineering programs. By adopting a holistic view that includes organizational, technical, and social subsystem analyses, the SEISS framework enables educational institutions to identify key factors that either support or hinder URM student success. This understanding is crucial for developing effective strategies to improve recruitment, retention, and overall academic performance of URM students. Additionally, the study's findings highlight the importance of communication and collaboration within and outside the educational system to foster a more inclusive and supportive environment for URM students. Ultimately, supporting URM students' success in engineering can contribute to a more diverse and innovative STEM workforce, which is essential for driving economic growth and addressing societal challenges.

Key Takeaways:
1. Holistic Framework: The SEISS framework provides a comprehensive approach to analyzing and improving the experiences of URM students in engineering programs by considering organizational, technical, and social factors.

2. Key Challenges: The study identifies major enabling and hindering attributes affecting URM student success, such as professional development opportunities, high school preparation, and issues related to curriculum difficulties.

3. Broader Impacts: Supporting URM students in engineering can lead to the development of role models and leaders, enhance diversity in the STEM workforce, and potentially drive innovation and economic growth.


Last Modified: 01/28/2025
Modified by: Arunkumar Pennathur
